HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 2, 1924

POST MORTEM
The honor of victory on the gridiron was claimed by neither
Johns Hopkins nor the University of Maryland on Thanksgiving
Day. Again the State Championship remains undecided. There
are no apologies on either side for the tied score. None are needed.
Both teams fought hard. The players gave their best in the struggle. With that we are content.

A co-operative agreement between the Johns Hopkins University and the United States Bureau
of Public Roads, Department of
Agriculture, Washington, D. C.,
has just been entered into for research upon the elastic properties
of concrete under the action of
rapidly applied loads.
It was determined by the Bureau at its experimental station at
Arlington, Virginia, a few years
ago, that the force applied upon
a concrete pavement by a moving
vehicle was several times as great
as that applied by the same vc
hide standing still. This "dynamic increment," commonly
called "impact," is due to inherent
roughness in the pavement and
the wheels of the vehicle, causing the wheels to actually jump
clear of the pavement in many
cases and then, under the action
of gravity and flexed springs, to
strike the pavement a severe blow.
The value of this impact load is
now susceptible of fairly accurate measurement.
From other experiments conducted at the same station, it is
also believed that material such as
concrete, whose elastic properties
are well known under static conditions, behave differently when
subjected to rapid applications ot
loads.
The whole question of proper
concrete highway design, involving the expenditure of millions of
dollars, depends upon accurate
knowledge of these elastic properties.
The investigation will be in
charge of Professor J. Trueman
Thompson of the Civil Engineering Faculty, who has been serving for the past four summers in
the capacity of Highway Research
Specialist in the Bureau of Public Roads. The testing apparatus,
designed by Professor Thompson,
will be built in the University
shops beginning immediately and
will be located in the "Concrete
Laboratory," C. E. Building.

Too much credit cannot be given to the team and to the coaches.
To the team, naturally, goes our unanimous praise and vote of appreciation. A heavier team, conceded the odds in every department of
the game, failed to score against the Hopkins squad. This fact in
itself speaks for the calibre of a Hopkins eleven. The Band and
those loyal rooters who followed the game also deserve a share of
the praise. After praise-giving to these elements, too many of us PLAY BY PLAY ACCOUNT OF
GAME
are likely to forget others to whom credit is due.
Football games, it has been said, are won and lost on the practice
field. The success of any team when it gets in a game depends
largely on the character of the practice it has had, for no matter how
strong the offensive tactics may be, a team is well on the way to
defeat when its defense is weak. It is the maltreated, forgotten
"scrub," who, to those not too well informed, keeps in because he
hasn't sense enough to quit, that turns out the well rounded varsity
team. The scrub player is absolutely essential. In many cases the
scrub gives his time and energy daily for four years that winning
teams may be produced. Yet, in many cases he receives no reward.
As the farmer is to the soldier in time of war, so is the scrub to the
team. He is "the man behind the lines" who is a measure of fighting
strength. The scrub, then, should rightly share honors equally with
the "first team."
Without any one of these elements, the team would not have
played so well on Thanksgiving Day. To teamwork on and off the
field we owe our success.

SHERWOOD EDDY
A world figure in Christian leadership, one with twenty-four
years' experience in international religious affairs, comes to Johns
Hopkins to address the student Assembly on "World Problems." Mr.
Sherwood Eddy, Yale '91, is the guest of the Y. M. C. A. and of the
University and as his hosts it behooves us to display to him such
courtesy as befits a man of his position in world affairs.

Dear Sir: Seniors hear from
their many friends each spring the
oft repeated advice, "Don't work
for a big corporation." This is just
one of the forms in which the advice is phrased; there are many others, but they all mean practically
the same thing. Why is it that this
advice is so prevalent? Why should
engineers be especially picked out
to receive this sort of advice? The
answers are not easily found, but
a refutation of the advice is readily
made to those engineers who are
expecting to start their life's work
this summer.
A big corporation presupposes a
successful corporation, for otherwise it could never have become big,
and to be successful it must be
practical. You have the theory but
you need practical experience, and
you can best get this in a big corporation where many branches of
engineering are used. From the field
thus brought before you, you can
choose safely the branch which you
want to follow throughout your
life.
But you ask if there is a chance
for advancement and is there room
near the top. There is plenty of
room near the to and if you fear
that you cannot push through the
crowds at the bottom the big corporations do not want you. They
want able, confident engineers.
Many large electrical corporations
offer graduate engineers a course
of one year in the shop to fit them
for their real work in dealing with
electrical problems as they arise in
the manufacturing industry. While
on this course the young engineer
is under. the supervision of the Educational Department, which at all

Dr. Blondheim, of the University faculty, addressed the Zionist
Society at their last meeting, Friday, November 21, on the changes
which have taken place recently
in Europe regarding the status of
Jews. The war brought about a
strong nationalistic feeling which
resulted in amity between the various elements making up each nation.
Towards the end of the
war, however, nationalistic feeling
died down and racial antagonisms
sprang up, bringing pogroms and
misery to the Jews of Europe.
The causes for such antagonism
are various. A general desire to
blame the war on someone, and
jealousy because of the remarkable financial success of Jews, particularly in Germany, are among
them. The chief instigators of
anti-Semitism were the old aris
tocratic families of Europe which
have always been enemies of Judaism. Members of these families, finding their positions threatened by the springing up of republics, and finding that Jews
were prospering under republican
governments and even taking part
in them, sought for selfish motives to rouse Anti-Semitism
among the people.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., DECEMBER 2, 1924

POST MORTEM
The honor of victory on the gridiron was claimed by neither
Johns Hopkins nor the University of Maryland on Thanksgiving
Day. Again the State Championship remains undecided. There
are no apologies on either side for the tied score. None are needed.
Both teams fought hard. The players gave their best in the struggle. With that we are content.

A co-operative agreement between the Johns Hopkins University and the United States Bureau
of Public Roads, Department of
Agriculture, Washington, D. C.,
has just been entered into for research upon the elastic properties
of concrete under the action of
rapidly applied loads.
It was determined by the Bureau at its experimental station at
Arlington, Virginia, a few years
ago, that the force applied upon
a concrete pavement by a moving
vehicle was several times as great
as that applied by the same vc
hide standing still. This "dynamic increment," commonly
called "impact," is due to inherent
roughness in the pavement and
the wheels of the vehicle, causing the wheels to actually jump
clear of the pavement in many
cases and then, under the action
of gravity and flexed springs, to
strike the pavement a severe blow.
The value of this impact load is
now susceptible of fairly accurate measurement.
From other experiments conducted at the same station, it is
also believed that material such as
concrete, whose elastic properties
are well known under static conditions, behave differently when
subjected to rapid applications ot
loads.
The whole question of proper
concrete highway design, involving the expenditure of millions of
dollars, depends upon accurate
knowledge of these elastic properties.
The investigation will be in
charge of Professor J. Trueman
Thompson of the Civil Engineering Faculty, who has been serving for the past four summers in
the capacity of Highway Research
Specialist in the Bureau of Public Roads. The testing apparatus,
designed by Professor Thompson,
will be built in the University
shops beginning immediately and
will be located in the "Concrete
Laboratory," C. E. Building.

Too much credit cannot be given to the team and to the coaches.
To the team, naturally, goes our unanimous praise and vote of appreciation. A heavier team, conceded the odds in every department of
the game, failed to score against the Hopkins squad. This fact in
itself speaks for the calibre of a Hopkins eleven. The Band and
those loyal rooters who followed the game also deserve a share of
the praise. After praise-giving to these elements, too many of us PLAY BY PLAY ACCOUNT OF
GAME
are likely to forget others to whom credit is due.
Football games, it has been said, are won and lost on the practice
field. The success of any team when it gets in a game depends
largely on the character of the practice it has had, for no matter how
strong the offensive tactics may be, a team is well on the way to
defeat when its defense is weak. It is the maltreated, forgotten
"scrub," who, to those not too well informed, keeps in because he
hasn't sense enough to quit, that turns out the well rounded varsity
team. The scrub player is absolutely essential. In many cases the
scrub gives his time and energy daily for four years that winning
teams may be produced. Yet, in many cases he receives no reward.
As the farmer is to the soldier in time of war, so is the scrub to the
team. He is "the man behind the lines" who is a measure of fighting
strength. The scrub, then, should rightly share honors equally with
the "first team."
Without any one of these elements, the team would not have
played so well on Thanksgiving Day. To teamwork on and off the
field we owe our success.

SHERWOOD EDDY
A world figure in Christian leadership, one with twenty-four
years' experience in international religious affairs, comes to Johns
Hopkins to address the student Assembly on "World Problems." Mr.
Sherwood Eddy, Yale '91, is the guest of the Y. M. C. A. and of the
University and as his hosts it behooves us to display to him such
courtesy as befits a man of his position in world affairs.

Dear Sir: Seniors hear from
their many friends each spring the
oft repeated advice, "Don't work
for a big corporation." This is just
one of the forms in which the advice is phrased; there are many others, but they all mean practically
the same thing. Why is it that this
advice is so prevalent? Why should
engineers be especially picked out
to receive this sort of advice? The
answers are not easily found, but
a refutation of the advice is readily
made to those engineers who are
expecting to start their life's work
this summer.
A big corporation presupposes a
successful corporation, for otherwise it could never have become big,
and to be successful it must be
practical. You have the theory but
you need practical experience, and
you can best get this in a big corporation where many branches of
engineering are used. From the field
thus brought before you, you can
choose safely the branch which you
want to follow throughout your
life.
But you ask if there is a chance
for advancement and is there room
near the top. There is plenty of
room near the to and if you fear
that you cannot push through the
crowds at the bottom the big corporations do not want you. They
want able, confident engineers.
Many large electrical corporations
offer graduate engineers a course
of one year in the shop to fit them
for their real work in dealing with
electrical problems as they arise in
the manufacturing industry. While
on this course the young engineer
is under. the supervision of the Educational Department, which at all

Dr. Blondheim, of the University faculty, addressed the Zionist
Society at their last meeting, Friday, November 21, on the changes
which have taken place recently
in Europe regarding the status of
Jews. The war brought about a
strong nationalistic feeling which
resulted in amity between the various elements making up each nation.
Towards the end of the
war, however, nationalistic feeling
died down and racial antagonisms
sprang up, bringing pogroms and
misery to the Jews of Europe.
The causes for such antagonism
are various. A general desire to
blame the war on someone, and
jealousy because of the remarkable financial success of Jews, particularly in Germany, are among
them. The chief instigators of
anti-Semitism were the old aris
tocratic families of Europe which
have always been enemies of Judaism. Members of these families, finding their positions threatened by the springing up of republics, and finding that Jews
were prospering under republican
governments and even taking part
in them, sought for selfish motives to rouse Anti-Semitism
among the people.
